qas.question: In modern secular usage Jews include how many groups?
What makes the definition of a Jew vary slightly?

answers.text: whether a religious or national approach to identity is used

qas.question: Which religion shares some characteristics of a nation, an ethnicity, a religion and a culture?
What doesn't share any characteristics with a nation?
How many groups do Jews include in modern religious usage?
How many groups do Jews include in historical secular usage?

plausible_answers.text: people who were born to a Jewish family

qas.question: Who is not included as a Jew in modern secular usage?

plausible_answers.text: whether a religious or national approach to identity is used

qas.question: What has no effect on the definition of who is a Jew?

context: <a2_0><b3_0>Judaism<b3_0/><a2_0/> shares some of the characteristics of a nation, an ethnicity, a religion, and a culture, making the definition of who is a Jew vary slightly depending on <a1_0><b7_0>whether a religious or national approach to identity is used<b7_0/><a1_0/>. Generally, in modern secular usage Jews include <a0_0><b4_0><b5_0>three<b5_0/><b4_0/><a0_0/> groups: <b6_0>people who were born to a Jewish family<b6_0/> regardless of whether or not they follow the religion, those who have some Jewish ancestral background or lineage (sometimes including those who do not have strictly matrilineal descent), and people without any Jewish ancestral background or lineage who have formally converted to Judaism and therefore are followers of the religion.
